'''''Bulgaria inquinans''''' is a [[fungus]] in the family [[Bulgariaceae]]. It is commonly known by the name '''black bulgar''' and '''Black Jelly Drops'''.<ref name="Collins">{{cite book|last=Sterry|first=Paul|author2=Hughes, Barry|title=Collins Complete Guide to British Mushrooms & Toadstools|editor=D & N Publishing|publisher=[[HarperCollins]]|location=London|year=2009|page=306|isbn=978-0-00-723224-6}}</ref><ref name=":0" />

It grows on branches and bark of dead [[oak]] and [[hornbeam]]. It has also been growing on [[Ash tree|ash trees]] due to [[Hymenoscyphus fraxineus|ash dieback disease]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.first-nature.com/fungi/bulgaria-inquinans.php|title=Bulgaria inquinans, Black Bulgar fungus|website=www.first-nature.com|access-date=2019-10-09}}</ref> The species can be found from October to March. It can be commonly found on felled trees stored in timber yards. Research into the colouring materials found in the fungus by H.Lockett and R.Edwards at [[Bradford University]] gave name to three purple [[biological pigment|pigments]] as two bulgarhodins and bulgarein.<ref name=Edwards1976>{{cite journal |title=Constituents of the Higher Fungi. Part XVI. Bulgarhodin and bulgarein, novel benzofluoranthenequinones from the fungus ''Bulgaria inquinans'' |journal=Journal of the Chemical Society, Perkin Transactions |volume=1 |year=1976 |pages=2149–55 |author=Edwards RL, Lockett HJ. |doi=10.1039/p19760002149}}</ref> 

== Description<ref name=":0" />==
The [[Pileus (mycology)|cap]] of ''Bulgaria inquinans'' generally has a diameter between 0.5 and 4 cm (0.19 in to  1.6 in). It has a flat top when young but later become more cupped. These mushrooms generally grow in medium sized clusters on dead trees, generally [[Oak]] and [[Hornbeam]], but also [[Fraxinus|Ash Trees.]] The texture of the mushroom is similar to leather or elastic, depending on dry weather (elastic like), or wet weather (leather). It grows across [[Continental Europe|mainland Europe]] and in the [[British Isles]], It also grows in parts of the [[United States]].
